Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing the physical world. However, it is not the only possible mathematical theory that could describe the physical world. In this paper, we provide a set of axioms that guarantee that a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. This provides a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is independent of any analytical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the origin and evolution of parasitic lifestyles. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, and maize is no exception. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere as the global mean temperature increases. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in savanna ecosystems. However, despite decades of research, we still do not know how diverse assemblages of these species coexist. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. Our results suggest that the extent of diet overlap is greater between species that are similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, and that dietary composition differs between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity is sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These findings suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This work highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms that drive coexistence in LMH assemblages. Such a synthesis may provide insights into the mechanisms that promote biodiversity in a world of limited resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the crisis on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses are planning to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with the application process. We also assess the resilience effects of the CARES Act loans relative to grants. Our results highlight the importance of providing financial support to small businesses during the COVID-19 crisis.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the marine environment. However, the global scale of the problem is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but that the total load is far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of the smaller plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may be of major importance to understand the fate of the missing plastic debris.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. This study provides a comprehensive reconstruction of the evolution of the global fishing fleet and its impact on the marine ecosystem. It is the first to disaggregate the data into three sectors, artisanal and industrial, and powered-artisanal vessels, and to estimate the engine power of the fleet. The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. It is also one of the most difficult to understand. This is because reproduction is a complex process that involves many different factors, and it is difficult to disentangle the relative importance of each factor. Here, we take a comparative approach to understand the factors that influence reproduction and the strength of their effect. We find that domestication and all forms of allocare correlate with increased fertility. All forms of provisioning correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase we observe in reproductive power is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work provides a new perspective on the evolution of reproduction and may have implications for human reproduction. (Less)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of this orphan disease.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against pathogens and debris. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The communication network is critical for the endothelium to control its functions and respond to the body’s needs. Here, we show that the communication network of endothelial cells is highly efficient and effective in controlling the functions of the endothelium. The network is composed of thousands of cells that are connected by short paths, which allows for rapid and robust communication between cells. The network is also highly dynamic, which allows for the endothelium to respond to changes in the body’s needs. These findings provide insights into the design of the communication network of endothelial cells and its role in controlling the cardiovascular system. They also provide a foundation for future studies on the regulation of endothelial function and the development of therapies to treat cardiovascular diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through a common software package and API, allowing researchers to easily access and combine the data. The data are useful for tracking the pandemic, for augmenting traditional public health reporting, and for empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a crucial residue for this allosteric communication and demonstrated that it is involved in the structural transition from closed-state inactivation to activation. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in human health and disease. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is not fully understood, and there is a need to identify new classes of molecules that could be used as therapeutics. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome.

Anxiety is a common feature of many psychiatric disorders, and the brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens (NAc) is known to be altered in these conditions. However, the role of the NAc in social behavior and social hierarchy is still unclear. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and that this is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the NAc. We also demonstrate that pharmacological inhibition of the mitochondrial respiratory chain in the NAc can alter social rank, and that this effect can be reversed by nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 that enhances brain energy metabolism. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the NAc as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. (Show more)

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein in red blood cells. The hemoglobin gene family is one of the largest in the human genome, and the expression of the different genes is regulated in a complex manner. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is involved in the regulation of hemoglobin expression.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy. One of the main reasons for this failure is the emergence of cancer resistance to therapy. In this study, we found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis are resistant to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We also found that this resistance is mediated by activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Finally, we demonstrated that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These results suggest that ferroptosis-inducing therapies may be used to overcome cancer resistance to therapy. This study may lead to the development of new cancer treatment strategies. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with an increased risk of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate a store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is mediated by the Ca2+ channel Cav1.2 and leads to up-regulation of the Ca2+ sensor protein STIM1. This pathway is important for the development of vascular remodeling in hypertension. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in patients with hypertension and cardiovascular remodeling. This study also suggests that LCCBs should be used with caution in patients with advanced age or advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area has been stable, but declined in two ecoregions—the Coast Range and Cascades—along with early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to forest management that considers the full range of ecosystem services and values. This is particularly important in the face of climate change, where the NWFP is expected to play a key role in the conservation of biodiversity.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with large datasets. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This makes the proposed network architecture a promising candidate for future applications.

The climate of the tropics is a key driver of the evolution of life on Earth. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the maintenance of immune tolerance is still not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. Moreover, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, we found that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in their genomes. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance cumulative cultural evolution. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and cumulative cultural evolution: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE is a protein that is produced by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. APOE is also a key protein in the classical complement cascade, which is involved in the clearance of senescent synapses. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of complement-coated senescent synapses in the brain. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of complement-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help to explain the increased risk of AD in APOE4 carriers. These studies also provide a potential target for the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is about 1,700 km in diameter and 1,500 km in height. It is the only solid ball in the universe. The inner core is the most mysterious part of the Earth. It is believed to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. Using a persistent embryo method and molecular dynamics simulations, we demonstrate that the metastable, body-centered, cubic phase of iron has a much higher nucleation rate than does the stable, hexagonal, close-packed phase under inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. They also provide a new approach to understanding the origin of other solid bodies in the universe. This work will help us understand the origin of the universe.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers show reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and in the brain as a whole when challenged with methylphenidate. These findings suggest that chronic marijuana use is associated with decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation, which might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the most complex cognitive skill that humans have evolved. How the human brain processes language is therefore a fundamental question in cognitive neuroscience. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural network language models make accurate predictions about the brain and behavior of human participants performing the language comprehension task of predicting the next word in a sentence. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the artificial intelligence revolution may be affecting us even as we write this abstract.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is still in its infancy and faces many challenges. One of the most fundamental challenges is that of instability. This paper shows that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a NN. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limits of algorithms in scientific computing and in machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time. This paper shows that the failure to act in time was not due to a lack of knowledge but rather to a failure of communication. The paper also shows that the failure of communication was due to a failure of science.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. The two species are very similar, but the causes of this similarity are not known. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a patient in Mexico and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species are very similar and that they have retained many of the same genes. This suggests that they are still able to cause similar diseases. This study also provides a framework for studying the evolution of leprosy. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two concepts that are most difficult to study in quantum systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be completely understood in the space–time scaling limit, thus providing a bridge between these two seemingly unrelated concepts. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vector technology, which have limitations. Here, we describe a live attenuated virus vaccine, COVI-VAC, that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on recoding the viral spike protein with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In hamsters, the vaccine reduced lung viral loads, lung pathology, and weight loss. Upon challenge with wild-type virus, the vaccine protected hamsters from almost all SARS-CoV-2–associated weight loss. Highly attenuated COVI-VAC is protective at a single intranasal dose in a relevant in vivo model. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This study provides a promising approach to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using multiple sources of data to understand the history of infectious diseases. Our results are also relevant to the current COVID-19 pandemic, where the role of human ectoparasites as vectors is currently being debated. Our results suggest that human ectoparasites may be important for the spread of COVID-19. Our model could be used to explore this hypothesis. (Show more)

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy to study the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased by the fact that brains of different species have different numbers of neurons. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size in amniotes is characterized by four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess. Interestingly, relative brain size is associated with relative neuronal cell density in reptiles, birds, and primates but not in other mammals. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of brain size and the cognitive abilities of animals.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense investigation. However, the function of TRAP1 in normal cells is less clear. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a more complete understanding of the function of TRAP1 in cancer. It also suggests that TRAP1 may be a useful target for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is also involved in many other cellular processes. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF/cofilin action is still unclear. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments under physiological conditions, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress. We propose a simple model that explains our experimental observations. Our findings have implications for understanding the function of ADF/cofilin in cells. They also have implications for understanding the role of mechanical stress in the action of ADF/cofilin. (Show more)

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and foods, is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian and Bantu populations are found. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We found that the Austronesian and Bantu populations are found on the island, and that the settlement history of Madagascar is complex. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, and that the genetic structure of the island is not only due to the admixture but also to the settlement history. These results are important for understanding the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Austronesian and Bantu populations. The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into a protein. The mRNA sequence is modified in many ways, and one of the most common modifications is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is present in the coding regions of mRNAs. The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of vertebrates in general. We use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints imposed by the aquatic medium to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the need to maintain energetic homeostasis.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of these chemicals on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture needs to be reduced worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the virus has spread to many animal species. The white-tailed deer is the most abundant cervid in North America and is susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive deer, and in deer during the peak of the human pandemic. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human transmission is at its lowest. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is still poorly understood. Here, we show that neurons are the major source of inflammatory factors in AD. We demonstrate that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons is the primary cause of the neuroinflammatory response, which is absent in neurons lacking Aβ. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The cellular response to stress is often accompanied by the accumulation of small RNAs. In bacteria, these RNAs are capped to facilitate their transport to the cytoplasm, where they are processed to generate 5′ termini that are recognized by a decapping enzyme. In this study, we show that the decapping of capped RNAs in Escherichia coli is accomplished by two different enzymes, one of which prefers to remove the cap from the 5′ end of the RNA. This enzyme is unique in that it prefers to remove the cap from a 5′ terminus that is not recognized by any other known RNA-dependent protein kinase. The unusual manner in which this enzyme recognizes capped 5′ termini could have major implications for the reprogramming of gene expression during stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the maintenance of homeostasis. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, an essential amino acid, is a key factor in the maintenance of immune homeostasis during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function during sepsis. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new therapeutic strategy to treat sepsis and other immune-mediated diseases. The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental property of the planet, but it is still unknown how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another. Here, we assemble a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life. We find that the biomass of the biosphere is dominated by plants, which are mainly terrestrial, whereas animals are mainly marine. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon observed in nature, such as sandpiles, fire, and earthquakes. SOC is characterized by the following properties: (i) the system is in a critical state, (ii) the system is self-stabilizing, and (iii) the system is scale invariant. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has only recently begun to be explored. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and allows for the discovery of previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to advance our understanding of the human microbiome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to contribute to the understanding of ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. Here we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient organisms. The results presented here are consistent with previous temperature estimates based on isotopic records.

This work represents a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides insights into the impact of ambient humidity on host response to influenza infection and disease outcome. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words as it processes a sentence. Whether and how this process unfolds in the brain remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity and is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in the development of many tissues. In vertebrates, there are two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a unique opportunity to understand the molecular mechanisms of gene regulation and evolution. It also provides a model for understanding the regulation of gene expression in other biological systems. This study is of interest to the general scientific community and the public. The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region for the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We have identified a critical downstream circuit element, the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which is necessary for this effect. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is not mediated by the VTA, but rather by a more caudal region of the VTA and the substantia nigra, and that this circuit is necessary for the development of overeating. This work provides a better understanding of the brain circuitry that may contribute to obesity. (Show more)

However, the efficiency of the nitrogen cycle in the soil is not fully utilized by plants, and the potential for improving this process is enormous. We have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen cycle in the soil, which could be used to improve the efficiency of the nitrogen cycle and thus the growth of plants.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and a critical ecosystem for the global climate. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This is an important contribution to the literature on the economics of deforestation.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in structure and function, and they are part of the animals’ bodies. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. Instead, it uses its web to listen to the world. The spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, and it is able to detect the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the spider’s eardrum. The spider can also adjust and regenerate its web according to its needs. This study provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function, which may be useful for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The health benefits are large because of the strong influence of air pollution on mortality and the strong influence of aerosols on rainfall. Our results show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has caused devastating outbreaks throughout human history, is a complex process that has been poorly understood due to a lack of ancient genomic data. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age across Eurasia. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a key strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural lands has the potential to accelerate SOC loss. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC stored in the mineral soil. These practices can also increase the amount of SOC stored in the soil organic matter fraction that is more resistant to decomposition and more likely to remain in the soil for centuries. These findings highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon on a large scale and provide a pathway for climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive approach to identifying and prioritizing viral threats to human health. We developed a risk assessment framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to systematically identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 viruses provides a comprehensive assessment of the zoonotic potential of wildlife viruses and can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a roadmap for the systematic identification of viral threats to human health and the development of tools to inform public health interventions.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of its chemical composition, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this compound. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for the study of the evolution of nectar chemistry. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly derived from northern and central Europe, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. This study also highlights the importance of female-biased migration in shaping the genetic landscape of Europe.

The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique insight into the molecular mechanism of lagging strand synthesis and the implications of the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme on DNA replication. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In the RNA world hypothesis, the first form of life was RNA-based, and proteins evolved later. In an effort toward reconstructing RNA-based life in the laboratory, we used in vitro evolution to improve the activity of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which is the core component of the RNA world hypothesis. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the realization of the RNA world hypothesis. (Read more)

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, which are the world’s most important carbon sinks. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is already affecting the performance of trees. Our results have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis in a Th17 transfer model. We also show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the most common cause is expansion of a single nucleotide in the gene for the RNA binding protein C9orf72. This opens up the possibility of rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify therapies for ALS. This will be of great importance for ALS patients and their families. The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. We now demonstrate that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which encodes a protein with several properties, including the ability to alter bacterial biofilm formation. IAFGP perturbs the tick gut microbiota, which influences the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier—critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. Mechanistically, IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector microbiome and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is poorly understood because of the limited known diversity of early branching members of the clade Pygostylia. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, which adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. This study also provides important information for understanding the origin of the modern avian body plan and the evolution of flight. (Less)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the atmosphere. In this paper, we show that the atmosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. The most famous example is the green coloration of many animals, which is called “chlorosis” and is thought to be a form of camouflage. We show that this phenomenon has evolved multiple times in frogs and toads, and that the green coloration is due to the presence of a specific protein, which binds biliverdin, the pigment of the blood. This discovery provides a molecular basis for the evolution of chlorosis and a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily. It also provides a new tool for studying the evolution of color in vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells. Here we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene encoding a pluripotency factor. We also show that ALKBH5 overexpression increases the capacity of breast cancer cells to initiate tumors in mice. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target in cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment used to make them has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. The method is noninvasive and can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment used to make pocket Bibles.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is controversial, but the timing and duration of the event are well constrained. The age model for the extinction is based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age model is used to explore the links between global environmental perturbation, carbon cycle disruption, mass extinction, and recovery at millennial timescales. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a major health problem, and the current treatment is limited. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the intestinal epithelium (IE) and is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIE-deficient mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor-binding domain of ACE2, the receptor for SARS-CoV, the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2002–2004. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein increases the flexibility of the receptor-binding domain, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This finding may help to explain the increased transmissibility of the mutant virus. Our results provide insights into the molecular basis of the increased transmissibility of the mutant virus. They also provide a basis for the development of vaccines that can protect against the mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) for finite games. Our proof is simpler and more general.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show that these properties can be used to predict and explain the chemistry of compounds under pressure. This work is a step toward the development of a chemical theory of the Earth.

Fire is a key natural process in many ecosystems, but its role in the climate system is uncertain. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant drivers of fire activity in the last century, and that these are likely to continue to shape the future. We find that climate change has already warmed the climate, and that this warming has been partially offset by changes in fire activity. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain, and the risk of more extreme fires is also high. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and the carbon cycle. This is critical for the development of effective climate mitigation strategies.

The gut microbiota is a major component of the human body, and its composition is known to be important for health. However, the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of the microbiota are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacterium is critical for the maintenance of the symbiosis.

Text data are ubiquitous and often contain latent patterns that can be used to understand the data and make predictions. However, the patterns are often not obvious and can be difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding. We first identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent words. We then infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. Our method is applied to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. This approach can be applied to many domains. We believe that it will be useful to researchers and practitioners.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, this assumption is based on a single hypothesis, which has not been tested. We show that the introduction of the bacterium into Europe was preceded by repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. Our results provide evidence for a complex history of plague introductions into Europe, which is likely to have shaped the course of the second plague pandemic. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its impact on human societies. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play an important role in the ecosystem. However, they are also a major prey item for sea stars, which are important predators in the marine ecosystem. In the Northeast Pacific, sea stars have recently experienced an extensive outbreak of wasting disease, which has led to the mass mortality of at least 20 species. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a disease outbreak in a marine invertebrate.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We found that the Austronesian and Bantu populations are found on the island, and that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization happened independently from Africa and Asia. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar and its impact on the island’s biodiversity and culture. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the backbone of the agricultural sector, providing information on crop status and condition to the government and the public. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily used for quantitative analysis. We propose a method to convert the original qualitative data into a continuous probabilistic variable, which is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting index is able to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of the crop expert network to provide a more accurate and timely assessment of crop status and condition, which can be used to improve agricultural management and decision-making. This is particularly important in the face of climate change, which is expected to have a significant impact on agricultural production.

Language processing involves the ability to store and integrate pieces of information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. It does not rely on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity for storage. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The origin of plastids and their evolution during the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy are among the most fundamental questions in biology. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes under progressively relaxed functional constraints during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that relaxed purifying selection in all plastid genes is linked to obligate parasitism, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for water resource management and climate change adaptation in SSA. It also highlights the importance of using high-resolution models for climate change impact studies. View Full-Text

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the discovery of quasicrystals in the laboratory has been slow and difficult. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, is significant because it represents the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. The discovery of this new quasicrystal in trinitite demonstrates that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. This work is significant because it provides a new context for the study of quasicrystals in the laboratory and in the natural world. It also provides a unique opportunity to study the effects of nuclear explosions on the environment. This work reveals that the reaction is catalyzed by three classes of enzyme in oxygenic and alphaproteobacterial phototrophs. These findings provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this reaction. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is known to be regulated by mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the regulation of neuroinflammation in both the early and later stages of EAE. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of neuroinflammation in EAE.
