The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest period in the state’s instrumental record and one of the most extreme droughts in the world. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. Our results have important implications for water management and climate change adaptation in California and other regions that are experiencing or will experience more extreme droughts in the future.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a starting point for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing new therapeutic approaches. (Show more)

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” The implications of this work for the study of news consumption, the media, and the psychology of human behavior are discussed.

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) cycle is a highly regulated pathway that plays a central role in many cellular processes. The store-operated Ca2+ release-activated Ca2+ (SOCRAC) channel is the main molecular component of this pathway. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) that result in constitutive activation of the SO-CRAC channel. We also identify mutations in the pore-forming protein of the SO-CRAC channel that result in reduced inactivation of the channel. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the SO-CRAC channel and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates by recipient neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous and that the release of aggregates from the cell is important for the spread of disease. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that targeting the release of aggregates may be an important therapeutic strategy. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. Mammals have both cytosolic SHMT1 and mitochondrial SHMT2, with the mitochondrial isozyme strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective cellular targets. We also show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. The increase seen across birth cohorts cannot be explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity for the less educated, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction pathway of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe emerging coronavirus infection that causes a high mortality rate. There is an urgent need for the development of antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential antiviral treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The gut microbiota is a major component of the human body, and its composition is known to influence many aspects of human health. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacterium is a mechanism for the host to control the composition of the microbiota.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis. The cell surface is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. This interface is critical for normal cell function and is also the site of many cancer-related processes. The 2020 presidential election is expected to be the most important election in the United States in a generation. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings have important implications for the 2020 election and beyond.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. The ability to regenerate neurons is a key feature of development and a valuable property for the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control the ability to regenerate in the adult nervous system are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway and is triggered by physical lesion of the neuron. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of neuronal outgrowth to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of injury-induced loss of function in the nervous system. (Show more)

Recombination is a fundamental process in the evolution of genomes. It is also a source of variation in the genetic makeup of organisms. We find that recombination is concentrated in regions of the genome called hotspots, and that these hotspots are distributed in a regular fashion across the genome. We also find that hotspots are concentrated in the promoter regions of genes. These results provide a detailed view of the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant. They may help us understand the evolution of recombination and its impact on the genetic makeup of organisms.

The resting brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in cognitive and emotional functions. However, the organization of these networks is not fully understood. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant network in healthy subjects and patients during rest and task performance. Network deactivation was reduced in early Parkinson’s disease, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a new perspective on the organization of the brain and its functional changes in health and disease.

The existence of a second 5′ modification of mRNA could have important implications for the regulation of gene expression.

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is particularly relevant for the conservation of biodiversity and the sustainable use of ecosystems.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by loss of movement control and motivation, and its cause is unknown. Here we show that the dopamine-producing cells are connected to other brain regions and to other parts of the substantia nigra by a network of specialized structures. These findings suggest that the disease is caused by a failure of communication within this network.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This may be important for understanding the evolution of social connection and for developing new technologies that can help us feel more connected.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cells, the sinoatrial (SA) cells, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SA cells are characterized by their ability to rapidly generate action potentials and maintain a stable heart rate. The heart rate is controlled by a number of factors, including the autonomic nervous system and hormones. In this study, we show that the activity of the SA cells is regulated by the store-operated Ca2+ entry channel STIM1. These findings reveal a previously unknown mechanism by which the activity of the SA cells is regulated. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of two key genes involved in JA signaling. These results suggest that Si may promote rice resistance against insect herbivores by priming JA-mediated defense responses. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in macrophage biology and may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory for language that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during normal activity. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic compounds or to seek out nutrients. Thus, they are dependent on the delivery of molecules to the cell for survival. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver molecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important for the internalization and gene silencing efficiency. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is important for the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient inputs to lakes come from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, ignoring the importance of small tributaries. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of coastal nutrient inputs, especially in areas where dams have altered the natural flow regime. Our findings highlight the need to expand monitoring and management efforts to small tributaries, which could help protect valuable nearshore ecosystems from the impacts of nutrient loading. This is especially important given the growing human population and associated demand for food and energy, both of which are expected to increase nutrient loading to aquatic ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding suggests that the ability to access rare combinations of chemical concentrations may be a key factor in the evolution of complex systems.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the effects of an antibody against the N-methyl-d-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) on cortical microcircuitry can lead to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. They also suggest that the same key parameters that can be tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition can lead to overt EEG paroxysms when these parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. This suggests that the same mechanisms may be involved in both conditions. This may help to explain the diversity of clinical symptoms in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and the consequences of such warming are of great interest. However, the history of abrupt warming events is poorly understood, and the mechanisms that control the response of the Earth system to such events are not well constrained. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the warming event was linked to the injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean and that the warming event was linked to the response of the Earth system to the injection of organic matter–derived carbon. These results provide insights into the mechanisms that control the response of the Earth system to abrupt warming events. This work also provides a case study for the use of carbon isotopes and uranium isotopes in the study of abrupt warming events.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification body for palm oil, and its certification is often required by major corporations and countries. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that most certified areas still contain substantial areas of peat and forest loss. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having the desired impact on deforestation and that certification alone is unlikely to be sufficient to meet the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement.

The exocyst complex is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. Its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental aspect of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination has been the focus of intense study. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination genes on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with multiple sex classes. We find that multiple sex determination genes can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of sex determination in animals.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species-generating lipofuscin and photodegrading species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of reactive oxygen species-generating lipofuscin and photodegrading species. We found that Fe levels impact the retina by influencing the levels of reactive oxygen species-generating lipofuscin and photodegrading species. These findings have implications for the understanding of retinal disease and for the development of therapeutic strategies. (Read more)

Siphonophores are one of the most diverse and abundant groups of pelagic cnidarians. They are characterized by the use of specialized side branches (tentacles) armed with nematocysts for prey capture. This is a highly specialized mode of feeding, and the only one in the animal kingdom. We show that the evolution of this mode of feeding has been linked to the evolution of other morphological structures and functional traits. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores has been driven by the evolution of morphological innovations and functional changes. These findings contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization in predators, and the evolution of morphological innovations in general.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the broader hominin fossil record. (Read more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. Mammals have both cytosolic SHMT1 and mitochondrial SHMT2, with the mitochondrial isozyme strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective cellular targets. We also show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT1/2, and for the development of targeted therapies for cancer and lymphoma. The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with an increasing number of people suffering from undernutrition and obesity. In addition, there is a growing concern about the impact of agricultural intensification on the environment. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by the presence of forests. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. The results also have implications for conservation, as forests are often overlooked in strategies to improve the environment. This study shows that forests can offer “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This is an important contribution to the literature on the relationship between agriculture and the environment.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher output and more food to be produced. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
